header.line: Composed and written by Michiel Kamermans
THIS FILE IS AT PRESENT STILL UNDER DEVELOPMENT AND SUBJECT TO CHANGE WITHOUT NOTICE

body.para: This document is not released under the creative commons or GPL license, but under the following license:

para.line: - You are not allowed to modify this document.
- Consequently, you are only allowed to redistribute this document in unmodified form.
- You may convert the data in this document to a different data format for either private or public polling.
- You may, however, not redistribute the data as converted format.

- When making parts of this data publically available, you will include this license text in some directly visible way (such as linking to a page with this license text, or verbatim copying it. Hiding it in html sourcecode or something that is not directly obvious does not fall under "directly visible").

body.para: In this license, redistribution is not the same as letting people view excerps such as when the data is used for instance on a searchable website
You can always contact if you feel you need to break these agreements, so we can talk over the particulars.

notice.para: Whenever you see "noun phrase" or "verb phrase", these are used as grammatical terms, meaning they entail single nouns and single verbs. I tried to separate use (ie: how is the prefix/suffix/contraction used in a sentece) from description (ie: what does it actually do). Should you notice an unnecessary overlap in an entry, please contact me so that this document can be updated.

Also, I use the term 已然形いぜんけい rather than 仮定形かていけい, mostly because the first is the grammatical name, and the second the colloquial name for this base. Since this dictionary concerns grammar, it would be odd to use 仮定形 instead.

You will see a lot of words in brackets in the example phrases. I used this styling to indicate contextually implied words that are not to be found in the Japanese sentence, but are required for a natural English translation. As always, personal pronouns are particularly fun: it doesn't matter which is used. Wherever you see one used, you can replace it with any other personal pronoun that fits the used case.

There will be entries which concern classical helper verbs. In these cases you will see a list of bases, such as for た: [たろ・×・た・た・たら・×]. This list is organised in the same way as any other Japanese dictionary organises them: [未然形・連用形・終止形・連体形・已然形・命令形]. An × indicates there is no such form.

You will need a browser that properly supports CSS2 (firefox, opera, netscape, safari) in order to "enjoy" the raw XML file; IE7 still does not support the rather important :before and :after pseudo-classes that this document uses for its field labels. If you are using IE for this document, please stop and either install the css2 fixes plugin for it (I have only been told this exists, you'll have to find it yourself), or install another browser alongside IE and be that bit more standards-adhering.

entry.description: Used in highly assertive speech, often following sentence ending だ (plain copula), か (questioning) or わ (emphatic). Possibly regional.
Honorifix prefix. Used (predominantly) for native Japanese words or words that use Japanse readings for their kanji.

example.phrase: お天気てんきがいいですね。
The weather is quite nice, isn't it?
example.explanation: The word "weather", 天気, has been made honorific, making the sentence as a whole softer.

entry.description: This particle marks a statement as being a questioning statement. Note this leads to more roles than just acting as question mark at the end of sentences.

example.phrase:
コンビニに行いった
か。
Did you go to the convenience store?
example.explanation: Without か, this phrase means "[I] went to the convenience store". The addition of か marks this as being in question instead.

example.phrase:
しよう
かと思おもった
I thought [about] whether I should do it.
example.explanation: Here the subphrase しよう is made a questioning statement, making the thought "shall [I] do?" rather than "[I] shall do". Like in the previous example, the subphrase しよう is in question, which is then stated as someone's thought.

example.phrase:
コーヒーにします
か、お茶ちゃにします
か。
Will you have coffee, or tea?
example.explanation: This is the "natural" interpretation of the choice operator "or", where two (or more) options are given, and only one of these may be chosen. Note that while in English this is one sentence, in Japanese this is necessarily two sentences in succession. Decomposed this sentence reads "will you have [coffee] or [tea]", with the parts in brackets being individual choices.

example.phrase:
コーヒー
かお茶ちゃにします
か。
Will you have [some] coffee or tea?
example.explanation: We see two "roles" of か here: the first is the "logical" interpration of "or", the second is what we would use a question mark for in English. Unlike the previous example the first か sets up a truth conditional, which is true if either coffee or tea or even both will be chosen. Unlike the previous example, which asks about which choice someone will go for, this question asks for a yes/no question. If answered yes, the speaker knows the listener will have any or all choices listed, and if no the speaker knows that none of the choices work. Decomposed this sentence reads "will you have [coffee or tea]" with the part in brackets being one thing, not distinct choices as such.

example.phrase:
いつ
か出でます。
[It] will come out eventually.
example.explanation: Normally いつ is a Japanese interrogative meaning "when". When affixed with か, all Japanese interrogatives turn into generic answers to these interrogatives: "when" becomes "some [unspecified] time", "where" becomes "some [unspecified] place", "what" becomes "some [unspecified] thing" and so forth.

entry.description: Marks the subject of a verbal clause. In some cases this may lead to が also leading to a perceived contrast in a sentence.

example.phrase:
母かあさん
が呼よんでたよ。
Mother called you.
example.explanation: In this sentence "mother" is the subject of the verb "call". Given the verb's meaning, this implies she's the one doing the calling, as what or who is called would be marked as direct object, which uses を in Japanese instead.

example.phrase:
それ
が好すきです。
I like that.
example.explanation: Since verbal adjectives do not have direct objects (adjectives only describe aspects of something, they do not act upon somethings) the thing they apply to is marked a subject to it. In this case the Japanese adjective 好き attributes the property of being-liked to the subject それ, "that". Note that "I" is completely implied and could just as well be any other personal pronoun.

example.phrase:
そう言いった
が、間違まちがってた。
I said that (lit: thusly), but I was wrong.
example.explanation: Here there is a weak contrast between the two statements. The second part is only a contrast to what the first part implies, rather than being a direct contrast. Essentially what we see here is that the entire phrase そう言った is the subject to the verb "being wrong".

example.phrase:
済すみません
が、通とおしてもらえませんか。
Excuse me, could [I have] you let me through?
example.explanation: For this example to make sense, it is required to know that すみません is not just an expression, but actually means something. Used in situations where a debt-relation is created (no matter how minor), this expression notes that after the situation has been resolved there will be a debt relation that prevails, rather than ending there and then (this debt by action has been at the basis of social interaction in Japanese culture throughout its history). Knowing this, the が in this example marks the expression as a "soft" subject; the "letting of someone through" is in this case fascilitated (though obviously not strictly speaking performed) by the expression. Usually example phrases of the kind "すみませんが、... " are explained as having が act as something different from the subject marker, but this is not quite true, it is merely a more subtle interpretation, made harder by the lack of such subtleties in English, which does not have explicit grammar markers but has to divide up the grammar in terms of roles. This example then not only explains the use of が in it, but also highlights the problem in explaining intrinsic differences between role-based and marker-based grammar explanation.

entry.description: A compound of か and い.

example.phrase:
行いくの
かい。
So: are you going?
example.explanation: The addition of い to the questioning particle か greatly emphasises the whole phrase. Without it, the Japanese would be better translated as merely reading "are you going?".

entry.description: A compound of か and な.

example.phrase:
これ、出来できる
かな。
I wonder if we can do this.
example.explanation: Note that "do" here refers only to the physical act of doing, not to the expression "... can do ..." that in English implies questioning whether social responsibility should be taken. The role of かな as dubitative comes from the combination of a questioning statement paired with な, which marks a statement as being almost rhetoric in seeking agreement. The addition of な leads to the statement 出来るか, "can [we] do?" being posed as an agreement seeking question "do you think we can do" without the explicit "do you" part. In English we write that as a self-posing question "I wonder whether ...", but this is strictly speaking not what happens in Japanese. The Japanese question remains one that is asked in a half-expecting-agreement fashion when there are listeners present (In the case that there is no one else present, this is a normal example of someone talking to themselves).

entry.description: A compound of が and な, expresses a hopefulness.

example.phrase:
前回ぜんかい来こなくて、今回こんかいはみんなが来きたらいい
がな。
Given the last time, it would be great if everyone showed up this time...
example.explanation: From the sentence it should be obvious that it is highly unlikely that the event "everyone will come" will indeed transpire. As such, the addition of がな makes this more a hope than anything.

entry.description: A compound of か and なあ.
A compound of が and なあ, expresses strong hopefulness
Marks a "base" event during which a shorter event takes place.

example.phrase:
散歩さんぽ
がてら買かい物ものしました。
I did some shopping while taking a walk
example.explanation: In this example the act of doing shopping is (far) shorter than the act of talking a walk. When using がてら the act to which it is affixed is always the longer "base" event. Usually you will hear the explanation that the shorter, more specific event follows the longer base event, but of course - as always in Japanese - what the speaker considers the most important comes last, so it is entirely possible to reverse the order provided we keep がてら affixed to the right thing: 買い物しました。散歩しがてら。 would be perfectly valid (if somewhat colloquial) Japanese.

entry.description: Denotes point of origin ("start") in terms of time, space, or reasoning.

example.phrase:
奈良なら
から来きました。
We came from Nara.
example.explanation: Here the starting point is the city of 奈良 (located in the 近畿きんき prefecture).

example.phrase:
十時じゅうじ
から暇ひまですよ。
I'll be free as of 10 o' clock.
example.explanation: Here the point in time "10 o' clock" is given as the starting point as of when "being available" applies.

example.phrase:
掃除そうじをして
からご飯はんを作つくります。
I will made dinner after [I am done with] cleaning.
example.explanation: Here the starting point for "making dinner" is set to the undefined moment when the act of "cleaning" is done. This uses the verb continuative て form rather than the past tense, as this indicates that the this act has not already been performed. If we use the past tense instead, then because the act has already been performed then this cannot act as a future moment in time, and will instead be interpreted as a reason, as in the following example.

example.phrase:
もう食たべた
から別べつにお腹なかは空すいてません。
I already ate, so I'm not particularly hungry.
example.explanation: Here the statement "I already ate" is used as argument to back up "I am not particularly hungry".

entry.description: A compound of から and して (て form of する). Marks a basis for (a series of) comment(s).

example.phrase:
服ふく
からして、彼かれは派手はでな男おとこですね。
[If we] start with his clothes, [it's clear] he's a pretty flashy guy.

entry.description: Effeminate particle, equivalent to かな.

example.phrase:
安やすくて買かおう
かしら。
It's [quite] expensive, I wonder if I should buy it.
example.explanation: This is the only truly effeminate particle in Japanese, used exclusively by women, transvestites, and particularly feminine gay men.

entry.description: A compound of か and よ.

example.phrase:
何なんで連絡れんらくしなかった
かよ。
Why [the hell] didn't you contact me?
example.explanation: The combination of か and よ is an extreme case of stressing, which is reflected in the translation by the English expletive "why the hell".

entry.description: Restricts a situation to only one case.

example.phrase:
一人ひとり
きりでその仕事しごとをしました。
I did that job on my own.
example.explanation: In this use きり is interchangable with だけ, with a nuance difference. The use of きり focusses on the fact that only one person did the job (implying there was no one else around to do it), while using でけ focusses on the fact that of a group of people only one person did the job.

example.phrase:
いすが少すくなくて、立たった
きり授業じゅぎょうを受うけた。
There were few chairs, so I [sat] through [the entire] class standing.
example.explanation: Here the act of "sitting through class" (an unfortunate English expression, which is only marginally related to actual sitting) is restricted to the a case of only being able to do this standing.

example.phrase:
ドイツへ行いった
きり帰かえって来こない。
After going to Germany he hasn't come back home.
example.explanation: Here the action statement "he hasn't come home" has been restricted to applying only to the case of "having gone to Germany". This pattern of きり plus a negative verb form is typically translatable as "after ... , ... ".

entry.description: Voiced version of きり, used mostly in reprimands.
A combination of "habit" and the affixing particle に. Used to indicate there is a norm from which is being deviated (negative connotation).

example.phrase:
ただのガキの
くせに偉えらい事ことも言いえるんですね。
You're just a kid, but you can say some profound things [sometimes] don't you?
example.explanation: Normally, kids are not really expected to say profound, so this would definitely be a deviation from the norm.

example.phrase:
いつも叱しかられる
くせに何なんで褒ほめてるんですか。
I'm always being scolded by you, why are you praising me [all of a sudden]?
example.explanation: If the norm has been established as "being scolded all the time", then being praised is a clear deviation from this norm.

entry.description: Marks rough extent in duration or action.

example.phrase:
一日いちにちに４時間よじかん
くらい勉強べんきょうします。
I study roughly four hours a day.
example.explanation: In this sentence the exact time statement ４時間, "four hours" is marked as rough estimate instead. Do not confuse with with the suffix ごろ, which does almost the same for exact moments in time (clock time), rather than duration.

example.phrase:
それ
くらい分わかっていますけど。
Well, that much I do understand...
example.explanation: In this example the word それ, contextually translatable as "that which was just said", is marked as the extend of the speaker's understood matter.

entry.description: Voiced version of くらい.
Equivalent to けども, using the concessive particle ど instead of ども.
Equivalent to けれども, formed out of the 已然形 of the classical verb き (which looks at the past) and classical concessive particle ども.
Equivalent to けれども, using the concessive particle ど instead of ども.

Contrastive conjunctive. Can be used in the forms けれども, けども, けれも and けど (following the old adage "the longer, the more formal"). This compound comes from the classical verb けり (which takes the present and looks back at it as past) in 已然形 suffixed with the classical compound particle ども (a concessive conjunction). From this combination the meaning of けれども is fairly immediate. This particle can be used either as conjunctive or interjection.

example.phrase:
ジャズもいいと思おもう
けど。
I think jazz [music] is good too, though.
example.explanation: This is an example of the interjection use, where it serves as a comment following up something said earlier, such as "I really love rock music".

example.phrase:
頑固がんこなやつだ
けれど、弟おとうとですからかわいくて当然とうぜんでしょう。
He's a stubborn guy, but he's [also] my brother, so obviously I love him.
example.explanation: In this example we see a normal contrast similar to the English "even though" or "despite".

entry.description: Honorifix prefix. Used (predominantly) for words that have been derived from Chinese or use Chinese readings for their kanji.

example.phrase: ご立派りっぱな女になられました。
[She] has become a fine woman.
example.explanation: The noun adjective 立派 is read using the chinese readings of its kanji, and gets ご rather than お as reading for the honorific prefix. (The なられる in this sentence is the honorific form of なる)

entry.description: Places emphasis on, or moves emphasis from something to, the preceding clause.

example.phrase: A: あっ、すみません。
Oh dear, excuse me.

B: いいえいいえ、こちら
こそどうもすみません。
No, no, excuse *me*.
example.explanation: This is an two phrase conversation in which こそ shifts emphasis away from speak A being to blame for whatever he or she is apologising for, to speaker B instead. You might hear this short "conversation" after two people bump into each other on the street when both weren't really looking where they were going.

example.phrase:
今度こんど
こそ勝かつわ。
*This* time we're going to win.
example.explanation: In this example こそ places emphatic stress of a level that is similar to adding explicit the contrast "unlike the previous times, this time we're going to win".

example.phrase:
だから
こそしなければならない。
[But] *that* is exactly why we should do it.
example.explanation: In this sentence こそ places emphatic stress on the preceding reason(s), referred to by だから.

entry.description: One of the two main divisions in Japanese, こと represents the "abstract" things as opposed to the "real" things (=もの). Follows verbal 連体形 or genitively linked to nouns, turning them into abstract concepts rather than the mundane thing they directly reference otherwise.

example.phrase:
彼かれの
事が嫌きらいだよ。
I [really] don't like him.
example.explanation: While translating the same as 彼が嫌いだ, the use of こと carries the consequences to an abstract level. Rather than disliking someone directly, in this example the speaker dislikes the person as he/she sees him. This is an important difference, as the way someone is seen need not reflect them in any significant way - something which goes for everything in life; the way you think about things need not reflect the way things truly are, and as such when forming opinions and the like, it sometimes helps to explicitly say you're talking about what you think, rather than assuming what you think is the way things really are.

example.phrase:
お箸はしを使つかう
ことは欧米人おうべいじんなどに変へんに見みえる。
Westerners [tend to] find the notion of using chopsticks [for eating] [quite] strange.
example.explanation: In this example こと turns the physical act of "using chopsticks" into an abstract notion, This notion is then said to be what Westerners find odd, rather than finding the act of someone using chopsticks when they come with a meal odd.

example.phrase:
日本にほんにしか行いった
事ことがありません。
I've never been to anywhere but Japan.
example.explanation: This example shows the use of こと in combination with a verb past tense, to turn 行った, "having gone to", into a noun construction 行ったこと meaning "the having gone to [somewhere by someone]". In effect, it has turned the physical event of having gone someone where to the abstract idea of going somewhere. This abstract idea is then commented on using ある, which says whether or not this notion applies to the speaker. In this case it does not: the going of some place other than Japan does not apply to this speaker. This interplay of verb past tense with こと and ある is used when describing whether or not someone has had experience with something.

entry.description: Marks rough moment in time. Do not confuse with くらい/ぐらい.

example.phrase:
三時さんじ
ごろ会あおうか。
Shall we meet up around 3?
example.explanation: In this example ごろ turns the exact clock time 3 o' clock into a rough clock time instead.

entry.description: This particle is used to mphasise bits of information as well as rhetorically confirm that a listener is still following the speaker.

example.phrase:
それで
さ、妹いもうとはな、俺おれの分ぶんまで食くってしまったよ。
So then, my sister [you know, who I was talking about,] even ate my portion as well.
example.explanation: In this sentence, there are actually three emphatic markers: さ, な and よ, of which the first two fulfil a similar role of grabbing the attention of the listener and making sure they're still following the conversation. This is similar to how ですね can be used as well.

example.phrase:
それなら、ある
さ。
Oh, well, that we have.
example.explanation: As a sentence ender, さ acts almost as a condescending marker, in this case by implying that someone's assumption about a certain product not being available is simply wrong. Without the さ, this phrase would just be translated as "We have that", but the さ at the end makes this phrase much more of a correction than just a remark.

entry.description: Used to mark a noun phrase as an extreme or severe case.

example.phrase:
金かね
さえあれば問題もんだいない。
As long as we've got money, there won't be any [real] problems.
example.explanation: In this example さえ marks money as being the only requirement to fulfill the situation "問題ない". In this use さえ can often be translated as "as long as", "if only ...".

entry.description: Used with 連体形 statements as a conjunctive either leading up to or explaining some conclusion or assumption

example.phrase:
結局けっきょく必要ひつようもなくて買かわなかった。高たかかった
し。
In the end I didn't really need it, so didn't buy it. [Plus,] it was expensive anyway.
example.explanation: The second bit is used as additional argument to explain the act of not buying a particular item.

entry.description: Used in the pattern [X]しか[Y] with Y being a negative verb, this particle marks the extent of the act Y as X.

example.phrase:
青空あおぞら
しか見みえない。
I see nothing but blue skies
example.explanation: This is a fairly self-evident example, where しか quite literally maps to "nothing but".

entry.description: A compound of しか and the 連用形 of する. Works as contrasting interjection.

example.phrase:
やっと準備じゅんびはできた。
しかし、君きみも来くるなんて思おもわなかったな。
[Well,] we're finally ready. Still, I didn't hadn't expected you to [want to] come along too.
example.explanation: In this example the contrast is not so much between the content of the two phrases, but between the situation and an expectancy. Typically when you are contrasting the literal information in two sentences using が or け(れ)ど(も) will be more "natural", as there is no need to use two separate sentences to contrast literal information. However, in this case there is a clear need to start a second sentence as the information in it is not directly related to the first sentence at all.

entry.description: Compound contraction of で and は.

example.phrase:
先生
じゃありません。
[I] am not a teacher.
example.explanation: In this example ではありません has been contracted to form じゃありません instead. Because of the ます form for ある this is still considered polite speech.

example.phrase:
それ
じゃ、またね。
Well then, see you later.
example.explanation: A somewhat expressive example, here the formal それでは has been replaced with the far less form それじゃ.

entry.description: The plain negative copula, not to be confused with the rhetorically questioning じゃない.

example.phrase:
この本ほんは辞典じてん
じゃないよ。
This book is not a dictionary [in case you thought it was].
example.explanation: This example is fairly self-evident.

entry.description: Hopeful rhetorical, used to verify that something is the case by asking whether the negative is the case. In this use it acts as a particle rather than verbal conjugation, and as such can follow verbal adjectives in 連体形. Do not confuse this use for improper negative inflection of verbals adjectives.

example.phrase:
その本ほんは辞典じてん
じゃない？
[Say,] isn't that book a dictionary?
example.explanation: The questioning tone makes all the difference here, without it this phrase would say "that book is not a dictionary", using the normal interpretation of じゃない.

example.phrase:
高たかいん
じゃない、五万円ごまんえん何て……
Isn't it a bit steep, at 50,000 yen...?
example.explanation: While normally verbal adjectives cannot possible inflect like nouns, relying on the copula, in this use we're not actually dealing with an inflection but with a "particle"; the speaker is somewhat hopeful rhetorically asking whether or not something isn't too expensive.

entry.description: Marks things over which an equal distribution of (countable) items is applied.

example.phrase:
少すこし
ずつ進すすんでいます。
I'm progressing [at something] bit by bit.
example.explanation: Here the equal distribution is of the action 進む per "bit".

entry.description: Used to mark a noun phrase as an extreme or severe case.

example.phrase:
友達ともだちに
すら話はなしていないことです。
It was something he had not even talked to his friends about.
example.explanation: The phrase 友達に話していないことです would mean "it was something he had not talked to his friends about", but the addition of すら (after に, preserving the chunk "to friends") marks the "to friends" bit as an extreme case for this particular type of action, leading to the translation given.

entry.description: Used in informal assertive language as emphatic marker, used when talking to equals or people of lower social status.

example.phrase:
つまらない趣味しゅみだ
ぜ。
Well, that's a boring hobby.
example.explanation: The "well" effectively comes from ぜ, which stresses the phrase つまらない趣味だ as subjectively informing someone.

entry.description: Used in informal assertive language as emphatic marker, used when talking to equals or people of lower social status

example.phrase:
つまらない趣味しゅみだ
ぞ。
[In case you didn't know,] it's [just] a boring hobby.
example.explanation: In this sentence ぞ stresses that something is mostly objective information. Contrast this to ぜ, which "feels" much more like subjective information.

entry.description: Classical helper verb for plain past tense [たろ・×・た・た・たら・×]. Contracts with 五段 verb 連用形: ～き+た → ～いた, ～ぎ+た → ～いだ, ～し+た → ～した, ～に+た → ～んだ, ～び+た → ～んだ, ～み+た → ～んだ, ～い+た → ～った, ～ち+た → ～った, ～り+た → ～った. The plain past tense is created in the same way for all verbs, following the 連用形 and in the case of 五段 verbs contracting in the abovementioned way. There are no exceptions to this rule, as even the two "irregular" verbs are regular in this respect, due to their irregularity being mostly in their bases (する → した, 来る → きた).

Plain copula, derived from にてあり, through である, where であ has become だ. This verb has some very curious bases: [だろ・だつ(で)・だ・(な)・なら・×]. As is evident from the bases, だ may change to な, but may also be replaced by の in some instances, or may even be omitted entirely in certain patterns.
First person desirative adjective (I want...), does not contract with 五段 verb 連用形.

example.phrase:
その新あたらしいゲームをやってみ
たい。
I want to try that new game.
example.explanation: This use of たい is considered about as subtle as a child saying "I want it, I want it, I want it" - it's egocentrical, to the point, and generally everything you shouldn't be when in unknown company.

example.phrase:
遊園地ゆうえんちに行いき
たいですけど……
example.explanation: As たい is an adjective, it can be made polite by adding the polite copula です (in some inflection). The けど acts as softening the expression further by hinting that the speaker would follow up with a statement that connotes "but only if this does not inconvenience anyone".

example.phrase:
休やすみはカナダに行いき
たいと思おもいます。
I think I'd like to go to Canada for my vacation.
example.explanation: To addition of と思う changes the meaning from "I want" to "I think I'd like", smoothing out the directness and making the expression quite suitable for general use.

entry.description: A compound of だ and い.

example.phrase:
で、何なん
だい？
So, what do you want?
example.explanation: As い is an interrogative, this entire phrase is essentially a question with the explicit addition of か to mark it as such.

entry.description: A compound of た (from たい) and the verb がる, meaning "seem to". Second/third person desirative adjective (I want...), does not contract with 五段 verb 連用形.

example.phrase:
その新あたらしいゲームをやり
たがるんです。
It seems like he wants try that new game.
example.explanation: This form only works as second or third person desirative, and so cannot mean "I want to try that new game".

entry.description: Represents a limit of action or quantity. Not as strict as きり.

example.phrase:
一人ひとり
だけでしました。
I did [it] on my own.
example.explanation: Because だけ rather than きり is used, we can assume that there were more people available to do this particular task, but that rather than doing it with several people, only one person ("me") performed it.

example.phrase:
出来できる
だけ早はやく来きて下ください。
Please come as quick as you can.
example.explanation: In this example the limit of "coming" is set to be whatever this person can muster. As an aside, this particular combination of 出来る and だけ can be confused with なるべく, which differs in meaning because of the words it's composed of. 出来る paired with だけ means "to the extent that you can", while なる paired with べく means "at your earliest convenience" ("the moment that it becomes a possibility").

entry.description: Emphatic alternative to verb ても form. Note that for 五段 verbs the same contraction rules apply as for the normal て form.
Emphatic alternative to でも (て form of です + も), as well as for the verb て form of -ぐ 五段 verbs.
Similar to そえ and すら.
Used for successive listing.

example.phrase:
犬いぬ
だの猫ねこ
だの、いろんなものを飼かっている
Dogs, cats, we have all sorts of pets.
example.explanation: Unlike とか and など, だの is a precise lister, and does not imply anything more than is listed.

entry.description: 已然形 of the past tense helper verb た. Past hypothetical verb form, used to talk about potential future action as if they already happened. Often used as conditional. Contracts with 五段 verbs in the same way as past tense た.

example.phrase:
先生せんせいに聞い
たらどうですか。
What if you asked the teacher?
example.explanation: While translated as a normal conditional, what actually happens is that the situation 先生に聞いた is sketches as already having happened. In effect this form presents a hypothetical past about which comments can be made.

entry.description: Derived from て+あり [たら・たり・たり・たる・たれ・たれ]. Used in combination with the verb する to representationally lists verb actions in the pattern [X]たり([Y]たり[Z]たり...)する. Unlike the verb て form, but like a regular 連用形, there is no sequence implied by this suffix. Contracts with 五段 verbs in the same way as past tense た or continuative て form.

example.phrase:
週末しゅうまつは読書どくしょし
たりしました。
I spent the weekend doing stuff like reading.
example.explanation: Regardless of whether it's used once or as a lister, ～たり has to be followd by an inflection of する for it to make sense.

example.phrase:
子猫達こねこたちが寝ね
たり遊あそん
だりして可愛かわいいですね。
Don't you think kittens are cute, how they sleep and play?
example.explanation: Here multiple たり clauses are used to create a list of actions that are performed by the kittens, though not necessarily in the order listed, and not necessarily at the moment that this phrase is used.

entry.description: Compound contraction of て and は.

example.phrase:
仕事しごとに行いかなく
ちゃ。
I [really] have to head for work.
example.explanation: The contraction here also serves as cut-off point for a trailing sentence, the full sentence would be 仕事に行かなくてはいけません (or variation on the double negative pattern for mandatory action).

entry.description: Glottal stop, added to words to signify the speaker is either cut off, or somehow feels it necessary to add the sense that the word is cut off.
Emphatic form of きり.
This particle is used as question recollective.

example.phrase:
電話番号でんわばんごうは何だ
っけ。
Now what was that phone number again...
example.explanation: This phrase should be interpreted as a recollective question, typically self-posed, but can also be asked as a "group" question, looking quizzically at someone who should be expected to know this too.

entry.description: Indicates a hypothetical action.
Emphasises an entire sentence

example.phrase:
ねえ。ね
ったら。
Hey... *HEY*
example.explanation: This example requires some explanation: the use of ったら only makes sense when trying to pull someone back into a conversation, and is typically added to statements intended for this purpose. The one given here is simply a speaker trying to get someone's attention by using the "empty" word ねえ, similar in role to the English "hey". The addition of ったら does roughly the same as repeating the word in English does, with added stress.

entry.description: Discouraged written form of ずつ in modern Japanese.
Quoting particle, contracted form of と言って. Sometimes used as a colloquial replacement for と in its quoting/stating role.
Verb conjunctive for listing verb actions with explicit sequence. 連用形 of the classical helper verb つ [て・て・つ・つ/る・つれ・てよ]. Contracts with 五段 verbs in the same way as past tense た.

example.phrase:
朝あさごはんを食たべ
て学校がっこうに行いきます。
I will eat breakfast and go to school [in that order].
example.explanation: the て form does not carry any intrinsic mood or tense, and so the last verb in a series of て statements indicates which inflection should be thought of. This may lead to confusion when て forms are used in a trailing sentence, where the actual operative verb is simply left off.

example.phrase:
赤あかく
て小ちいさなカバンを買かいました。
I bought a red, small bag.
example.explanation: While sequence does not matter for adjectival properties, it does matter in delivery; the later in the series, the more impotant the speaker is likely to consider the property. Note that here is an exception to the て form for verbal adjectives, being ない. This adjective can either inflect regularly as なくて, or almost noun-adjectivally in the form ないで. The latter is colloquially used, the former is more literary style. It should also be noted that the て form can be ignored in colloquial speech, where listing properties can simply be done with the verbal adjective in 連体形 - noun adjectives still require the て form of です (で) for chaining.

example.phrase:
疲つかれ
て、そろそろ寝ねます。
I'm tired, so I'll be going to sleep soon.
example.explanation: This is basically the same as sequence listing, but because of the meaning of the words used it can be translated as giving a reason for something. The japanese literally just reads "I am tired, I will go to bed soon". The "so" given in the English translation is merely there to turn the English slightly more natural sounding, but it is this tendency that has earned て a repuation of somehow also being able to state reason; technically it doesn't do this at all.

entry.description: Marks a noun as instrument of an action.

example.phrase:
これを筆ふで
で書かきました。
I wrote this with a brush.
example.explanation: In this phrase the brush is the instrument for writing, and as such as is marked with で.

example.phrase:
タクシー
で空港くうこうに行いきました。
We went to the airport by taxi.
example.explanation: In this phrase the taxi is the "instrument" by which 'going to the airport' is performed, and as such is marked with で.

entry.description: Used with location nouns or noun phrases to emphasise location of an event or action, rather than the action or event itself.

example.phrase:
池いけにあるホテル
で泊とまった。
We stayed the night at a hotel by the lake.
example.explanation: This phrase should be interpreted as answering the question "Where did you stay the night". This phrase focusses explicitly on the "where" of matters, not on the "what-is-done" of matters. It is possible to get confused by looking at the English translation only, as one might think this could also be an answer to the question "what did you do [during your trip]", but in Japanese there is no such mistake possible; で explicitly marks "where", while に explicitly marks "what", so it is impossible to get confused about the interpretation of a sentence as long as we are looking at a Japanese phrase. If instead a translation from English is required, then the choice becomes somewhat arbitrary, as a translation cannot be given without first deciding which aspect should be focussed on.

entry.description: て form of the polite copula です.

example.phrase:
父ちちは54歳さい
で、母ははは52歳さいです。
My father is 54, my mother 52.
example.explanation: This is the simplest use of です in て form, where the two separate factoids 父が54歳です and 母が52歳です are joined into a single sentence, with the subject markers replaced by context markers instead as we now have two subphrases that can be placed in each other's context. (see the entry on は for a more detailed explanation of this use).

example.phrase:
彼女かのじょが静とずか
で小ちいさくて目めに付つかない人ひとです。
She's quiet, small, not someone you'd notice.
example.explanation: This is essentially no different from the previous example where で is used as a continuative, except that there is a sense of "chaining" of attributes going on.

entry.description: A compound of the て form of です and さえ.
Polite copula.

example.phrase:
これは鉛筆えんぴつ
です。
This is a pencil.
example.explanation: です defines one item as something else, however due to context sensitivity in Japanese, the actual item itself may be omitted. There are several copula constructions of which です is the most neural polite. Alternatives are だ, である, だござる and でいらっしゃる.

entry.description: Used midsentence, this construction can be used to emphasise bits of information as well as rhetorically confirm that a listener is still following the speaker.

example.phrase:
それは
ですね、考かんがえてたんだけど、やっぱり駄目だめだと思おもいますよ。
About that; I gave the matter some thought, but I think it won't do any good.
example.explanation: As regular sentence それはです would make no grammatical sense at all, but as an attention grabbing interjection ですね does nothing more than to add in a little unexpected word to get a listenere to take note (possibly "again", to keep them engaged in the conversation).

entry.description: Combination of verb て form and は, used for remarking on the quality of a verb action, usually in a negative sense. Colloquially contracted to ちゃ.

example.phrase:
今日きょうこなく
ては絶対ぜったい駄目だめです。
You *have* to come today.
example.explanation: A more literal translation, in part illustrating how the natural translation came to be, would be "Not coming today really won't do". The continuative act "not coming today" gives rise to the comment that this will not do.

entry.description: A combination of で and は. Colloquially contracted to じゃ.

example.phrase:
そう
ではないか。
It that so?
example.explanation: An interrogative question, using the more formal counterpart to じゃない.

example.phrase: では、お休やすみなさい。
Well then, good night.
example.explanation: This use of では is also colloquially performed by じゃ.

entry.description: Colloquial contracted form of と言えば, used to emphatically introduce a topic.
A compound of the verb conjunctive て and contrasting も.

example.phrase:
電話でんわをかけ
ても日曜日にちようびで誰だれも来こないわ。
Even if you call them, it being a sunday no one will come by.
example.explanation: The act of calling is sketched as futile by ても, further elaborated on by the rest of the sentence.

entry.description: A compound of the て form of です and contrasting も.

example.phrase:
先生せんせい
でも分わからないものがあるんでしょう。
[But isn't it the case that] even as a teacher there things you don't understand.
example.explanation: In this example phrase the case of being a teacher is sketched as not being excempt from certain conditions.

example.phrase: でも、とうやって説明せつめいしていいですか。
But, how should I go about explaining this?
example.explanation: When used at the start of a sentence, でも acts as contrasting interjection, similar in meaning to the English "even so".

entry.description: Accompaniment particle. This particle translates as several different things in english, all following from the concept of accompaniment: noun listing, personal or conceptual accompaniment, simultaneous conditional, onomatopoeic/mimetic illustration, and quoting/stating. These translations apply to combinations of と with plain nouns, people, verb phrases, onomatopoeia/mimesis, and full phrases respectively.

example.phrase:
飲のみ物ものは牛乳ぎゅうにゅう
とジュースを買ってきた。
For drinks I bought milk and juice.
example.explanation: Here the list "milk and juice" represents an inclusive list. In this use と is not required for the last item in the list.

example.phrase:
その映画えいがを友達ともだち
と見みに行いった。
I went to go see that film with a friend.
example.explanation: In this use と

example.phrase:
彼かれが首くびになる
と俺おれも退社たいしゃする。
If he gets fired, I resign too.
example.explanation: The concept of と as accompaniment is very important here: this is not the traditional if/then relation that will be familiar in English, but two actions accompanying each other: they are linked. Within the context that exists, either both happen, or both don't happen.

example.phrase:
雨あめがザー
と降ふってきた。
The rain came pouring down.
example.explanation: You will not find onomatopoeia back in a Japanese translation, as they fulfill meaningful roles in Japanese, unlike in English where they are considered sound effects. In Japanese onomatopoeia are used to clarify certain aspects of certain events, and are used in animate spech. In this particular example, the onomatopoeia ザー represents the sound of pouring rain, leading to an English translation using the word "pouring". This qualification of events using onomatopoeia comes from と making the onomatopoeia an accompaniment to some event.

example.phrase:
月光げっこうで海うみがきらきら
と光ひかった。
The moonlight made the sea light up sparkling.
example.explanation: In this translation "sparkling" does not come from a verb, but from the adverbial construction きらきらと, which adds the aspect of きらきら, a mimesis representing sparkling, to the event of lighting up, 光る.

example.phrase:
部屋へやを片付かたづけて
とお母かあさんが言いいました。
"Clean up your room," said mother.
example.explanation: Because of what と means, there is no direct need for quotes in the original Japanese in order for it to be understood that a quote is being delivered. With quote symbols, the phrase would look like 「部屋を片付けて」とお母さんが言いました.

example.phrase:
それ程ほどよくない
と思うけど……
I don't think it's that good...
example.explanation: This sentence states the phrase それ程よくない as a thought, though the verb 思う can be replaced with any other verb that can be used to state something (say, think, think about, know, inform, etc.).

entry.description: A compound of と and か. Marks nouns or noun phrases as loosely representational items. Can be used on its own or in listing fashion.

example.phrase: A: 食たべ物ものの中なかに何なにが好すきですか。
What kind of foods do you like?

B: 甘あまいものが好すきです。アイス
とか、お菓子かし
とかね。
I like sweet things. Things like ice cream and confectionary [you know?].
example.explanation: Rather than give an exact, single answer, person B choses to list several items that meet his/her criteria instead.

entry.description: A compound of と (typically in the personal accompaniment interpretation) and の.
A compound of と and も, can act in both interpretations of も

example.phrase:
いつか君きみ
とも別わかれるんだ。
One day we'll say our goodbyes too.
example.explanation: The correct interpretation of this sentence is that 君 is marked as an extreme in a way, similar to what ても does for verbs.

example.phrase:
何なにをしよう
とも、無意味むいみだ。
No matter what you do [now], it will be meaningless.
example.explanation: This is essentially the same as the first example, but then for verbs instead of nouns. See ても.

example.phrase: A: 帰かえってもいいですか。
Is it okay if I go home?

B: ええ、いい
とも。
Certainly.
example.explanation: Literally B says "yes, this is okay", but emphatically marks the statement as unquestionable.

entry.description: Aside from the literal "place", Indicates a conceptual "point".

example.phrase:
叱しかる
ところまで行いく
To go so far as to scold [someone].
example.explanation: In this phrase ところ indicates the extent of something by marking the point up to which certain behaviour will go.

example.phrase:
あの人ひとは全まったくいい
ところがない。
That person really has no good points [to them].
example.explanation: In this phrase ところ marks attribute "points".

example.phrase:
危あぶない
ところへ来きてしまった。
They [unfortunately] arrived at a dangerous point in time.
example.explanation: In this phrase ところ simply marks a point in time which happens to be (in this case) dangerous.

example.role: temporal point, based on an event
example.phrase:
ちょうど手紙てがみを書かいた
ところ彼女かのじょが電話でんわした。
Just as I wrote her letter, she called.
example.explanation: Here ところ marks a point in time as indicated by a certain event.

entry.description: Voiced version of ところ, used for
Marks prohibitive command.
"Strong" version of ね.
Sound changed version of the plain copula だ, if followed by の.
"Strong" version of ねえ.
Marks the subordinate action in a situation where two actions are performed simultaneously.
A compound of ながら and contrasting も.
Marks nouns or noun phrases as loosely (categorially) representational. Can be used on its own or in listing fashion. Having come from なに+と through なんと, can colloquially be used as なんか.
Marks the situation as an event happens.
The 已然形 of the plain copula だ, used as shorthand form for the plain noun hypothetical conditional ならば.
Compound of なら and ば. Acts as hypothetical conditional form for nouns.
Colloquial form of など.
Belittles or downplays something. Colloquial particle.
Rhetorical sentence ending particle, assumes agreement.
More emphatic version of ね

Affixing particle. This particle translates as several different things in english, all following from the concept of affixing: specifying time (point or interval), specifying location (specific or loose), specifying reasoning (specific or loose), specifying relational objects or actors to verb actions. In all these roles the particle に merely affixes an additional specific element to base information. Do not confuse the role of に affixing location, or "destination", with the role that へ plays in marking direction rather than destination.

roles.role: any affixing prepositional statement (in, at, to, by, for, from, with)

entry.description: A compound of に and て, formal version of instrumental で.
A compound of に and は. Creates a contrast in addition to affixing (further) specification.
A compound of に and も.

Genetive particle, denotes a conceptual "following from" relation between the suffixed noun or nounphrase as origin. This relation translates as several different things in english, all following from this concept: posession, direct relation, and taxonomical specification
Follows 連体形. Nominalises a verb phrase.
This is a soft emphatic, used in reserved speech.
Genetive particle used as replacement for the plain copula だ in certain phrase patterns using subphrase.
Informal version of のです.

Verb continuitive て form of のです, indicates an objective causative. As it stresses objective information, it cannot be used to specify requests, opinions, commands, invitations, suggestions or volitional actions. Is used as formal counterpart to から, if used to specify objective cause.

Compound of nominalising の and polite copula です. Marks a phrase as explanation or justification of a particular assumption by someone or situation someone is in. When used in a question (followed by か), this construction asks for such an explanation or justification (while a copula question, this pattern forces the answer to be in a のです better too, rather than a yes/no form).

A compound of the nominalising の + reasoning affixing に. Sets up a contrast between what follows, and what would be expected given what precedes it. Not to be confused with genetive の + relational object に, which is not special in any way.
Formal counterpart to だけ and ばかり.

Topic or contextual information marker. Pronounced わ. Using は for information that does not seem contextual "forces" a listener or reader to find a context in which this information would make sense as contextual information, typically leading to the statement being interpreted as contrasting in some way.
Marks an hypothetical conditional (in contrast to the simultaneous conditional と, or hypothetical past future たら).
Colloquial version of ばかり.
Marks something as being so dominant it represses all other things. Also used in the more emphatic versions ばかし, ばっかし, ばっかり or ばっか.
Marks something as being an expectation.

example.explanation: Because it is commonly translated with "should", this particle may be confused with べき (べし), as the word "should" in English can signify either an expectation or a (social) obligation. The first interpretation is reserved for はず, the second for べき (べし)

entry.description: Colloquial emphatic version of ばかり.
Colloquial version of ばかり.
Colloquial emphatic version of ばかり.

Marks a direction of travel or motion. Pronounced え. Do not confuse へ with に as affixing particle for location, interpreted as "destination". In a line of travel, へ marks only the line without regard for the end points, に marks only the end point.
Follows 連体形. Marks something as being a (social) obligation. This is the 連体形 of the classical adjective べし.

example.explanation: Special case: すべき rather than するべき

entry.description: Classical adjective, follows 連体形. Marks something as being a (social) obligation. While technically an abolished 終止形 form, this word is still in use in modern Japanese, and can be used interchangably with the more "modern" 連体形 form べき.
A compound of へ and の.
Marks the degree of something, which is interpreted as extent for actions, or approximate amount for quantities. In this second role it is comparable to くらい/ぐらい
Changes the meaning of a preceding phrase to "other than ...", and is followed by a negative verb to indicate that excluding the mentioned phrase, nothing else applies.

Indicates the extent of something for which から can act as origin. This means not just time or space, but also reasoning or arguments (i.e: carrying an argument too far). まで represents exclusive extent, meaning "up to" but not "up to and including" (see までに).
A compound of まで and affixing に. Means "up to and including", as opposed to まで meaning merely "up to".
A compound of まで and the genitive の.
A compound of まで and も. Indicates the non-existent of an extent (that might otherwise be assumed).
Honorifix prefix. Used (predominantly) for words relating to the emperor or emperial matters.

Equality marker. This particle can be used in two ways that are considered distinct in English, but follow from the concept of equality: similarity (two objects being equal in some respect) and uniformness (a certain concept can be said to consist of any number of parts, each of which is equal to any other in some [same] respect).

One of the two main divisions in Japanese, もの represents the "real" things as opposed to the "abstract" things (=こと). Used as particle it marks the preceding phrase as a "real" (either observed or socially implied) reason or motivation for certain behaviour. Note that this behaviour does not need to be explicit and can be implied by what someone says instead. Colloquially shortened to もん.
A compound of もの and か. Used as sentence ending to phrases in negative form to emphasise this negative. Formally used as ものですか (colloquially もんですか) or colloquially as もんか.
A compound of もの and the verb conjunctive て form of です. Colloquially used as もんで.
A compound of もの and なら. Colloquially used as もんなら.
A compound of もの and を. Expresses a dissatisfaction over an issue.
Colloquial form of もの.
Colloquial form of ものか.
Colloquial form of もので.
Colloquial form of ものなら.
Open noun listing particle. Implies more items than are listed.
string hopeful rhetoric, similar to じゃない.
Emphatic particle, added to phrases or even subphrases to underline some part of dialog.
Subordinance marker. Used in formal writing as replacement for から.
In "standard" Japanese an effeminate (in most other regional dialects of Japanese a neutral gender) emphatic, softer than よ
Colloquial open noun listing particle
A compound of わ and い.
Direct object marker. Pronounced お.
A compound of を and は, which is sound changed in this comination. Used mainly in classical style Japanese to raise a matter of concern using を and then discuss it as contextual information using は.
Contracted form of のだ.
Contracted form of のです.
